The smaller the pack, the more enjoyable your travel will be.
If you don't have to make the trip about yourself you don't need so much cloth. If you go in hot inexpensive countries, you can buy extra stuff there if you realize you need more or you are unexpectedly invite to see some king or prince...
The ideal for hot countries is to have 1 bag that can be taken in cabin with you:
No luggage registration (saved me from missing some planes because of delays due to accidents on the way to the airport), no stolen or lost luggage, no waiting at the arrival for your luggage.
You can easily walk with your pack and you can always buy an extra bag if you need to take back some stuff.
Remember that people live in those countries, so you will probably find all you need there.

Hey Elena! Indian girl here
Few tips: use Uber or ola(Indian version of Uber) and don't use local cabs cause they might charge you extravagantly. Stay hydrated cause heat strokes are very common here. And buy only packaged water bottles like bisleri, aquafina, kinley. Ask for those in restaurants instead of drinking the water they serve you(even if they claim it's RO). Your immune system isn't adapted to the weather and water so try not to eat uncooked food like chaats. If you are in Delhi or any of the other northern states then please be cautious of your surroundings. Keep everything locked at all times. If you're having trouble navigating or feel uncomfortable, look for women(preferably younger ones who're usually fluent in English). If you feel uncomfortable at any point, then speak out, people will help you out.
Hope you have a wonderful time here! It really is quite safe nowadays but since you are well dressed and (hate to say it) white, people will think that you have a lot of money to spare and ask for ridiculous amounts of money. Otherwise I'm sure you're gonna love it here!

I hitch hiked in the northern part of India back in October. It was such a cool experience. It was so freeing and opened my eyes to what traveling can really be like. 

Long story short, I met a few guys in a hostel my first day in Delhi, and ended up spending a few weeks traveling with them. We went to Leh, Ladakh (northern India) and hitched a ride from there to Diskit. There were pretty insane roads up there: picture unpaved, rocky, and exposed cliffs. Went over a very high mountain pass at nearly 18000 feet (5480m). We had to split off into two hitched rides because it was hard as a group of 3 to get a lift. Our driver in the car I rode in was so kind and refused money from us. We even stopped for some hand-made noodles in the most delicious thukpa soup on the way and tried butter tea. They had a sweet dog in the car and I had to sit in the middle seat so the dog could have the window seat üòÇ

Tried to hitch a ride a few days later up to Turtuk, but after spending 4 hours trying to hitch a ride and getting caught in a sand storm, we ended up having to get a taxi. The taxi driver was over an hour late lol. It was a crazy day. 

Hitch hiking is awesome. Be careful especially if you‚Äôre a woman! I felt safe because I was traveling with two men, but otherwise *personally* I wouldn‚Äôt have hitch hiked. But that‚Äôs just me :)

I disagree that hitchhiking is all about luck. I've hitched all over the world for decades, and there are lots of things you can do when hitching to increase or decrease your chances of getting lifts. Main thing is don't hitch on fast roads, but find spots where cars are going slow enough to see you and react in time, and make sure there's a very easy and safe place cars can pull over for you. Look presentable enough, dont obscure your face with sunglasses etc, wear bright clothes if possible, make sure your backpack is visible so people know you're a backpacker. Don't just get in any car that stops, but ask where they're going and see if the place they're going will be a help or a hindrance to getting the next ride. Carry a physical detailed road map of the country/area you're in, as the map will have key information that Google Maps doesn't, such as petrol station locations. When doing the hitching itself, make sure your hitching arm and thumb are clearly outstretched, and not just resting down. A whiteboard, whiteboard markers, and rag can be very useful, even just as a prop. The more props you can display that indicate you're hitchhiking the better. Oustretched thumb, prominently visible backpack, readable sign with one or two words maximum. The sign isn't really necessary in a lot of situations but it can be a lifesaver sometimes. Some people say hitching should only be done during the day, but I've found that in some places, getting to a truck stop petrol station in the evening when trucks are doing longhaul trips can be useful if you just want to get where you're going and don't care about the scenery. Truckers will 99.99% never stop for you when they're moving, but the chances of one saying yes when you talk to them when they're parked or refuelling is very high. I could go on, but that's the basics I can think of

And a woman who held a baby against her bosom said, Speak to us of Children.
     And he said:
     Your children are not your children.

     They come through you but not from you,
     And though they are with you yet they belong not to you.
